												After all these years, why should anyone keep playing ARMA: Gold Edition? The controls are clunky. The graphics are old. AI can't fly or drive worth a hoot. It almost seems designed to repel newcomers. But...... this game rewards the patient and those willing to look past a number of technical flaws. Aside from the other ARMA games, no other FPS titles even attempt this level of realism, not even Codemasters' iterations of Operation Flashpoint. With its unforgiving difficulty and unparalleled depth (and I'm serious about the depth; look up Dslyecxi's ARMA guide, where he makes reference to FM 21-75 because the advice therein is applicable) it is among the closest approximations of war we are ever likely to see in a videogame. ARMA: Gold Edition is not just for military enthusiasts. Anti-war persons may also like it, since it has potential to dissuade you from ever joining the military (and seeing as the game consists of dehumanizing long range combat where you're killed by stray bullets from enemies you never get to see, it might conceivably have that effect). For those of you who like the original Ghost Recon, try this. It's just a little bit harder.

												I have nearly 500 games in my Steam account, and the vast majority of them are still unplayed. So now I'm dedicating an hour to each of these games and writing a series of One Hour Reviews. An hour isn't very long to judge a game on, so think of this as more of a first impression, and take this review in the spirit in which it's given. Be sure to read other reviews from players who have spent more time in the game. One Hour Reviews - Game 11Arma - Gold EditionPurchase Date: 1/16/2014I ended up getting a bunch of the Arma games as part of a Humble Bundle.  I only really heard of Arma because of the DayZ mod that everyone talks about.   Normally this isn't the kind of game I would be looking to buy, but I appreciate that the Humble Bundle gives me a good excuse to try out some games I'd otherwise ignore.The first thing I did when I started the game was go right to the graphics options.  Since Arma has been out for awhile, it looks a little dated, but this also means that I can crank up all of the graphics options to make it look as nice as possible.  Arma gives plenty of options to tweak, much as you'd expect from a modern game.Since I had no idea how to play or what I was doing, I made sure to start with the tutorial.  Arma provides a series of tutorial missions, starting with a basic obstacle course to run through.  It gave me the option to do a run through first without being timed, which I'm glad it did as it took me a little bit to get used to the controls.I had an issue with the default mouse controls.  By default Arma is configured to have this huge 'floating' area on the mouse.  This floating area defines how far you can move the mouse before the camera moves.  So it's kind of a sensitivity thing, but for me it just made the controls feel super laggy.  Luckily the options menu let me turn this all the way down.  I can't imagine why someone would want it configured otherwise.Once I had the controls nailed down, I finished the obstacle course, with the drill sargeant barking at me as I went.  Next up was a shooting range, so I could have a chance to get used to all of the weapons.  The game offers various lanes, each with a different weapon.  The game gives certifications on each weapon, based on how well you can shoot.  First I trailed with a rifle, then a sub-machine gun, followed by a pistol.  I ended up doing pretty well with these, but then I bombed with the grenade launcher.  The last lane contained a sniper rifle.  The next tutorial introduced me to my squad, and consisted of me giving my squad various commands.  I found this part of the tutorial rather cumbersome.  I get that this is a simulator so it's supposed to be in-depth and give a lot of options.  But it also seems a lot harder to get things done than it should be.  I hit a key to toggle my whole squad, but it wasn't really obvious to me when all of my squad was selected.  I wish it had been a little easier to know which squad members were selected and which ones weren't. The squad menu has an impressive list of options.  I can do things like order my squad into a particular formation, or move the squad members to a waypoint.  This took some getting used to; in particular I had a hard time getting my squad to enter a vehicle I had targetted.I should mention that the game is fully voiced, which sounds nice, but I wasn't the biggest fan of the implementation.  Some of the voicing was fine, like in the earlier tutorial where the drill sargeant was bossing me around.  But I didn't like the squad voicing as much.  A lot of the dialog is stitched together dynamically, where words were recorded one at a time, and then spliced into sentences.  When played back like this, it just doesn't sound natural, and it's kind of jarring.Once I got the basics of squad combat down, the next tutorial put me in a tank.  This ended up being pretty fun as I rode around and fired at various targets with different weapons on the tank.  Again I struggled with the controls, and remembering which key is supposed to switch weapons.  I liked how the game simulates the different positions in the tank, as I went between driving, gunning, and commanding.  I mentioned above about the dialog being stitched together.  This got really old when I was trying to command the tank to move back to the base.  I had a hard time telling which direction the tank was facing, so I kept hitting keys to rotate the tank.  Every time I hit a key, the game would bark that command to the driver.  I kept hitting keys in fairly rapid succession, and the game kept barking commands like I was directing some kind of demented Simon Says game.Once I parked the tank, the final tutorial mission I took part in was flying a helicopter.  The mission starts out with the helicopter pilot telling me to get in and fly, and he'll join me as a co-pilot.  So I hopped in the helicopter and started up the engine, and the game proceeds to explain the controls.  So I take the helicopter up slowly as directed.  Then the co-pilot starts yelling at me because I left him behind.  Oops!  It was kind of hilarious because on one hand, the game is happily telling me how to fly, and on the other hand my co-pilot is screaming at me from the ground.  I tried to land the helicopter so I could let the co-pilot board but instead I ended up killing the co-pilot with the helicopter blades approximately .5 seconds before I crashed the helicopter and died.I ended up restarting the mission so I could get a proper start.  This time with my co-pilot in the copter, I took off and started flying around.  It didn't take me long to realize that I am pretty terrible at this.  I was doing okay until the game wanted me to hover, which I couldn't do at all.  I finally ended up skipping that step in the mission, and next the game had me go to pick up some soliders.  Instead I ended up crashing the helicopter.  Predictably I died.At this point I was over my hour, and I didn't get to check out the final tutorial, which would have taken the helicopter into combat.  It's probably just as well I didn't try that one, given my meager piloting skills.So I'm left deciding whether to give this game a thumbs up or thumbs down.  I'm going to be reviewing Arma II next, so I'll be curious to see how it differs from this one. I'm really pretty torn here because this was really a mixed bag of things I liked and things I didn't.  I can see where this game would be fun, and I know I barely scratched the surface of what the game has to offer.  But I also have to be honest with myself and realize that I don't see myself bothering to come back to this game.  So based on this I'm going to have to go with the thumbs down.
